articles.headline: Move to Restrict Pain Killers Puts Onus on Doctors
articles.snippet: Regulators in Washington State are attempting to stem what some see as the excessive use of prescribed narcotics.
articles.abstract: Regulators in Washington State are attempting to stem what some see as the excessive use of prescribed narcotics.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an unusual move, a state government is developing regulations meant to stop doctors from prescribing higher doses of powerful  and often dangerous  pain killers for patients who are not benefiting from them.

articles.headline: Russia Moves to Sell Shares in State Companies
articles.snippet: The government plans to sell only minority stakes in the companies, retaining control while letting investors share a larger part of the risks and profits.
articles.abstract: The government plans to sell only minority stakes in the companies, retaining control while letting investors share a larger part of the risks and profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  The Russian government, which just a few years ago was salting away billions of dollars in oil revenue, is now confronting such a gaping budget deficit that ministers approved a wide-ranging plan on Wednesday to sell off state property, senior officials said.

articles.headline: Judge Blocks Arizona’s Immigration Law
articles.snippet: A preliminary injunction was issued against parts of the law, including the sections that called for officers to check a person’s immigration status while enforcing other laws.
articles.abstract: A preliminary injunction was issued against parts of the law, including the sections that called for officers to check a person’s immigration status while enforcing other laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX  A federal judge on Wednesday blocked the most controversial parts of Arizona’s immigration enforcement law from going into effect, a ruling that at least temporarily squashed a state policy that had inflamed the national debate over immigration.

articles.headline: Reliable Dictation, Down to a ‘T’
articles.snippet: The company Nuance offers a new version of Dragon NaturallySpeaking, proving that even near-monopolies like to tinker with their products.
articles.abstract: The company Nuance offers a new version of Dragon NaturallySpeaking, proving that even near-monopolies like to tinker with their products.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nuance, the company that makes Dragon NaturallySpeaking for Windows, is in a pretty sweet position: It’s essentially a monopoly. One by one, its competitors in the speech-recognition business have either left the market (Philips), gone out of business (Lernout & Hauspie) or turned over its product to Nuance (I.B.M.). Even the sole Mac speech-recognition program, MacSpeech Dictate, can no longer be considered a kind of rival; Nuance bought it this year.

articles.headline: Congress Rethinks Its Ban on Internet Gambling
articles.snippet: Under pressure to find new revenue sources, Congress is reconsidering legalizing, and taxing, Internet gambling.
articles.abstract: Under pressure to find new revenue sources, Congress is reconsidering legalizing, and taxing, Internet gambling.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  With pressure mounting on the federal government to find new revenues, Congress is considering legalizing, and taxing, an activity it banned just four years ago: Internet gambling.

articles.headline: In Price War, New Kindle Sells for $139
articles.snippet: Amazon.com, the maker of the Kindle e-reader, is introducing two new smaller, lighter versions with high-contrast screens and crisper text.
articles.abstract: Amazon.com, the maker of the Kindle e-reader, is introducing two new smaller, lighter versions with high-contrast screens and crisper text.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE  Amazon.com will introduce two new versions of the Kindle e-reader on Thursday, one for $139, the lowest price yet for the device.

articles.headline: U.S. Military Scrutinizes Leaks for Risks to Afghans
articles.snippet: Some of the documents released by WikiLeaks contain the names of Afghans who gave information to NATO troops.
articles.abstract: Some of the documents released by WikiLeaks contain the names of Afghans who gave information to NATO troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon is reviewing tens of thousands of classified battlefield reports made public this week about the war in Afghanistan to determine whether Afghan informants were identified and could be at risk of reprisals, American officials said Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Job Subsidies Also Provide Help to Private Sector
articles.snippet: Stimulus money sometimes goes to private companies to hire workers, instead of funding public projects.
articles.abstract: Stimulus money sometimes goes to private companies to hire workers, instead of funding public projects.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — States are putting hundreds of thousands of people directly into jobs through programs reminiscent of the more ambitious work projects of the Great Depression.
